conclusion: Analyze basketball's motion with air resistance
Basketball dropped from height H, rebounds to height h, air resistance force magnitude λmg
Find ratio of post-collision velocity to pre-collision velocity
Define variables: v1 (velocity before collision), v2 (velocity after collision), e (coefficient of restitution)
Net acceleration downward is g(1-λ)
Velocity just before collision v1 = sqrt(2g(1-λ)H)
Net acceleration upward is -g(1+λ)
Velocity just after collision v2 = sqrt(2g(1+λ)h)
Coefficient of restitution e = -sqrt((1+λ)h/(1-λ)H)
Constraint 0 < λ < (H-h)/(H+h)
Verify e is consistent with reaching height h
Reconsider constraint λ = (H-h)/(H+h)
Use conservation of energy with dissipation
Initial potential energy PE_i = mgH
Energy before collision KE_1 = mg(1-λ)H
Energy after collision KE_2 = e^2 * mg(1-λ)H
Energy at maximum height PE_f = mgh
Work done by air resistance during upward motion is λmg * h
Equation mgh(1+λ) = e^2 * mg(1-λ)H
Solve for e: e = sqrt(h(1+λ)/H(1-λ))
Determine e directly using constraint
Image shows brake warning sign and cars undergoing emergency braking
For inelastic collision, ratio of rebound height to initial height equals e^2
Ratio of post-collision to pre-collision velocity is e = sqrt(h/H)
